sect2.title: Installation of Logrotate
sect2.para: Install logrotate by running the following command:

screen.userinput:
sed -i '/exit 5/s/^/echo uncompress failed -- skipping #/' test/test &&
./configure --prefix=/usr && make

sect2.para: To test the results, issue: make test.

sect2.title: Command Explanations
sect2.para: sed ... test/test: Prevents the tests from failing due to a problem in the test script.

sect2.title: Configuring Logrotate
sect2.para: Logrotate needs a configuration file, which must be passed as an argument to the command when executed. Create the file as the root user:

screen.userinput:
cat > /etc/logrotate.conf << EOF # Begin of /etc/logrotate.conf
# Rotate log files weekly weekly
# Don't mail logs to anybody nomail
# If the log file is empty, it will not be rotated notifempty
# Number of backups that will be kept # This will keep the 2 newest backups only rotate 2
# Create new empty files after rotating old ones # This will create empty log files, with owner # set to root, group set to sys, and permissions 644 create 0664 root sys
# Compress the backups with gzip compress
# No packages own lastlog or wtmp -- rotate them here /var/log/wtmp { monthly create 0664 root utmp rotate 1 }
/var/log/lastlog { monthly rotate 1 }
# Some packages drop log rotation info in this directory # so we include any file in it. include /etc/logrotate.d
# End of /etc/logrotate.conf EOF
chmod -v 0644 /etc/logrotate.conf

sect2.para: Now create the /etc/logrotate.d directory as the root user:
At this point additional log rotation commands can be entered, typically in the /etc/logrotate.d directory. For example:

screen.userinput:
cat > /etc/logrotate.d/sys.log << EOF /var/log/sys.log { # If the log file is larger than 100kb, rotate it size 100k rotate 5 weekly postrotate /bin/killall -HUP syslogd endscript } EOF
chmod -v 0644 /etc/logrotate.d/sys.log

sect2.para: You can designate multiple files in one entry:

screen.userinput:
cat > /etc/logrotate.d/example.log << EOF file1 file2 file3 { ... postrotate ... endscript } EOF
chmod -v 0644 /etc/logrotate.d/example.log

sect2.para:
You can use in the same line the list of files: file1 file2 file3. See the logrotate man page or
for more examples.

The command logrotate /etc/logrotate.conf can be run manually, however, the command should be run daily. Other useful commands are logrotate -d /etc/logrotate.conf for debugging purposes and logrotate -f /etc/logrotate.conf forcing the logrotate commands to be run immediately. Combining the previous options -df, you can debug the effect of the force command. When debugging, the command is only simulated, not really run, thus, eventual non-existing errors appear, when some intermediate files are expected, because they are not actually created.
To set up to run logrotate ... at 3AM daily, root's crontab should be edited to add:

listitem.para: performs the log maintenance functions defined in the configuration files.
